qas.question: What is the term for the arrangement of two unpaired electrons in dioxygen?
How is the O2 molecule referred to in its ground state?
What causes triplet oxygen to react slowly?
What type of combustion does the slow reaction of triplet oxygen prevent?
What are the weakly filled higher orbitals of oxygen?
What is the ground state of the O molecule referred to as?

plausible_answers.text: combination of cancellations and σ and π overlaps

qas.question: What results in dioxygen's triplet bond character?
What does double oxygen react slowly with?
What does double oxygen reacting slowly with most organic molecules prevent?

context:
This <b6_0>combination of cancellations and σ and π overlaps<b6_0/> results in dioxygen's double bond character and reactivity, and a triplet electronic ground state. An electron configuration with two unpaired electrons as found in dioxygen (see the filled π* orbitals in the diagram), orbitals that are of equal energy—i.e., degenerate—is a configuration termed <a0_4>a <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><a0_3>spin triplet state<a0_4/><a0_3/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>. Hence, the ground state of the <a1_1>O<a1_1/>
2 molecule is referred to as <a1_0><a1_2><a1_3><a1_4><b5_0>triplet oxygen<b5_0/><a1_4/><a1_3/><a1_2/><a1_0/>.[b] The highest energy, partially filled orbitals are <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2><a4_3><a4_4>antibonding<a4_4/><a4_3/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/>, and so their filling weakens the bond order from three to two. <a2_3>Because of <a2_1><a2_2>its <a2_0><a2_4>unpaired electrons<a2_4/><a2_3/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>, triplet oxygen reacts only slowly with <b7_0>most organic molecules<b7_0/>, which have paired electron spins; this prevents <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><a3_3><a3_4><b8_0>spontaneous<a3_3/><a3_2/><a3_0/> combustion<b8_0/><a3_4/><a3_1/>.
